titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the W. Lloyd Wright papers, 1786-1945 MS2075
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-05-18 14:26:18 -0400.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.unittitle: W. Lloyd Wright papers
did.abstract: Collection includes correspondence, bills, receipts, lottery tickets, proclamations, testimonials, auction catalogue, newspapers, bonds, stock certificates, and checks. The material dates from 1786-1945. All of the material in this collection relates to prominent people and activities in Washington, D.C.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: W. Lloyd Wright papers, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The W. (William) Lloyd Wright Collection was donated to the University by Wright's sister Mathilda Wright following his death in 1950.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

bioghist.head: Historical or Biographical Note
bioghist.p: W. (William) Lloyd Wright (1876-1950) was a draftsman and engineer for the U.S. Navy, and a collector of manuscripts, photographs, and pamphlets.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection includes correspondence, bills, receipts, lottery tickets, proclamations, testimonials, auction catalogue, newspapers, bonds, stock certificates, and checks. The material dates from 1786-1945. All of the material in this collection relates to prominent people and activities in Washington, D.C.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: Correspondence, Financial papers, and Miscellaneous.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Folders in Series 1 Box 4 were re-numbered in Aspace to reflect the numbering of the physical folders in the box. Previously, Box 4 had been numbered with Folders 24-48 in Aspace. Now, they are numbered 1-25 in Aspace and in the physical box. 3/12/2020

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was reviewed in 2022 to address outdated descriptive language. During that revision, staff did not edit the description, but provided additional information to add context. Description issues were located in the Collection Abstract and Scope and Content note, as well as Series 1 and 2 Scope notes. To see the description prior to revisions, please view the previous version of Cody Pfanstiehl papers finding aid.

did.unittitle: Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence that dates from 1795-1906. The 117 letters in this series are from prominent Washingtonians, such as W.W. Corcoran, banker and philanthropist, Peter Force, historian, printer, and member of the Washington, D.C. city council, and Horatio Greenough, an American sculptor known for his controversial statue of George Washington. Also included are letters from Joseph Gales and William Seaton (both journalists and mayors of Washington, D.C.), George Washington Riggs, banker and one of the founders of the Corcoran and Riggs banking firm, and Robert Mills, architect of the Washington Monument.

processinfo.head: Historical Context
processinfo.p: The term "prominent" is considered to be an aggrandizing term and usually would be avoided in archival description. The example in the Scope and Contents note of Series 1 was left as is, as the term "prominent" shows why the correspondence was aquired and preserved.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was revised in 2022 to address outdated descriptive language. During that revision, staff did not edit the description but instead added a context note. To see the description prior to review, please view the previous version of the W. Lloyd Wright finding aid.

did.unittitle: Adlum, John (1759-1836). Letter: Philadelphia, to Aaron Ogden

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Requests permission from Col. Ogden to take three weeks from duty to see to his farm duties. (Adlum was a vintner, and wrote a memoir on the "cultivation of the vine in America," which is in Special Collections, call number SB 389 .A28).

did.unittitle: Baird, Spencer Fullerton (1823-1887). Letter: Washington, DC, to E.S. Morse

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Asks for an illustration from a book by Morse, to be used in a Smithsonian Institution publication. (Baird was Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution from 1879-1882).

did.unittitle: Barber, Virgil (1782-1847). Letter: Georgetown College, to Silas Wood

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Sends information on a former Georgetown student; mentions planned move to Jusuits' house in Washington. (Barber was an Episcopal, then Catholic clergyman, who taught at Georgetown University).

did.unittitle: Barlow, Ruth (1755-1818). Letter: to Pamela Jacob, Windsor, Vt.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Mentions arrival at Mason's Island (now Theodore Roosevelt's Island) on Oct. 22. Expresses pessimism about the ability of the U.S. to win the War of 1812. (Ruth Baldwin Barlow married poet and diplomat John Barlow in 1781).

did.unittitle: Barlow, Ruth (1755-1818). Letter: Kalorama, to Pamela Jacob, Windsor, Vt

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Mentions long hours of business correspondence, her granddaughter, and her affection for Mrs. Jacobs.

did.unittitle: Blake, George B. Letter: City of Washington, to Col. John S. Cunningham

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Argues that the true name of the capital of the United States is City of Washington, not Washington. (Blake was a member of the Association of the Oldest Inhabitants of the District of Columbia).

did.unittitle: Blodget, Samuel (1757-1814). Letter: to Daniel Gilman

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Concerns financial dealings. (Blodget was a merchant, land speculator, and architect, especially in the early District of Columbia. He died bankrupt).

did.unittitle: Bomford, George (1792-1848). Letter: Washington, to Gen. J. Manton

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Concerns transfer of artillery from New York state. (Bomford was a soldier, ordnance expert, and a resident of Washington, D.C.).

did.unittitle: Burnett, Frances Hodgson. Letter: 1770 Mass. Ave., to Ms. Scott

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Apologizes for not writing before, says has been in England and has just returned because of son's illness. (Burnett was an author, especially of children's books, and was a resident of Washington, D.C., 1876-1898).

did.unittitle: Causten, Anna Payne. Letter: Washington, to unidentified recipient, between 1809 and 1817.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Mentions her Aunt Dolley Madison's severe cold and the visitors she received. Also mentions President James Madison. (Causten was the niece of Dolley Madison and lived with her in the White House).

did.unittitle: Cooke, Henry David (1825-1881). Letter: Washington, to Richard Cruikshank

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Approves the use of a District of Columbia government building for the use of a public library. (Cooke was the brother of banker Jay Cooke and the first governor of Washington, D.C., 1871-1873).

did.unittitle: Cooke, Henry David (1825-1881). Letter: Washington, to Gardner Rand, Troy, N.Y.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Sends his autograph and says he has resigned as governor of Washington, D.C.

did.unittitle: Cooke, Henry David (1825-1881). Letter: Washington, DC, to Andrew J Rogers, Wash.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Tells Rogers he is unable to make an appointment, although he is in favor of developing the water power of Great Falls of the Potomac.

did.unittitle: Corcoran, W.W. (1798-1888). Letter: Washington, DC, to Dr. James Laurie, Wash.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Mentions willingness to pay any balance outstanding on his account. (Corcoran was a Washington, D.C. banker and philanthropist).

did.unittitle: Corcoran, W.W. (1798-1888). Note: to "Dear Madam"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Thanks recipient for sending account of the death of a friend.

did.unittitle: Coxe, Richard Smith. (1792-1865). Letter: Georgetown, to Garret Wall, Trenton, NJ

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Describes his lack of political influence in Washington. Comments on the personalities of President James Monroe and John C. Calhoun. Describes the general atmosphere of the U.S. Congress. (Coxe was a New Jersey lawyer who moved to Washington, D.C. in 1822 and developed a large legal practice).

did.unittitle: Cranch, William (1769-1855). Letter: Washington, DC., to Robert G. Harper, Baltimore

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Explains the judge's verdict in a legal case involving the Marine Insurance Company of Alexandria, to Harper, a Baltimore lawyer and former representative from South Carolina. (Cranch was the Chief Justice of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, 1805-1855).

did.unittitle: Cranch, William (1769-1855). Letter: Washington, DC, to the New North Society, Boston

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Ms signed by Cranch and two others, as Committee of Management of the First Unitarian Church in the city of Washington. Invites representatives to the ordination of their new pastor, Cazneau Palfrey.

did.unittitle: Cunningham, William. The Washingtonian: holograph

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Prospectus for a semi-weekly newspaper of political thought.

did.unittitle: Custis, George Washington Parke (1781-1857). Letter: Alexandria, DC, to R.B. Taney

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Asks Taney's help in receiving compensation for fisheries destroyed on his property, caused by dredging the Potomac River to improve Georgetown navigation. (Custis was a playwright and the step-grandson of George Washington).

did.unittitle: Cutler, Manasseh (1742-1823). Letter: Washington, to [Jedidiah] Morse, Charlestown, Mass.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Holograph signed. Mentions the opening of Congress. Asks Morse to forward a religious pamphlet. Speaks disparagingly of writings of Thomas Paine.

did.unittitle: Dahlgren, Madeleine Vinton (1825-1898). Letter: to Mr. Harvey

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Concerns her article on the social status of women. (Dahlgren was a Washington author).

did.unittitle: Davenport, Braxton. Letter of Republicans rest, to Jeremy Robinson, Wash. City

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Welcomes his friend back to Washington; praises Robinson's selection of an attractive widow as a friend.

did.unittitle: De Cow, Rachel. Letter: Washington, to unidentified recipient

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Thanks recipient for sending a check; requests he sell a property for her; mentions her brother's financial difficulties in raising a large family.

did.unittitle: Dickins, Asbury (1780-1861). Letter: Washington, to Hyde de Neuville

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Informs the recipient he has been elected a resident member of the Columbian Institute in Washington, D.C. (Dickins was a secretary of the U.S. Senate in Washington, D.C. and a secretary of the Columbian Institute).

did.unittitle: Douglass, Frederick (1817-1895). Letter: Washington, DC, to B.F. Underwood

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Is arranging to send a copy of his autobiography; is an interested reader of the Index, of which Underwood is editor. (Douglass was born a slave and later became an American diplomat and journalist).

did.unittitle: Ellicott, Andrew (1754-1820). Letter: to the President and Directors of the Office of Discount and Deposit

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Asks to postpone for six months the payment of a note. (Ellicott was a surveyor and mathematician, who drew up early maps of the District of Columbia).

did.unittitle: Fendall, Phillip Ricard (1794-1868). Letter: Washington, to Daniel Webster

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Accepts from Webster, Secretary of State, the appointment as U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia. (Fendall was a Washington lawyer and U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia).

did.unittitle: Fendall, Phillip Ricard (1794-1868). Letter: Washington, to Henry Clay

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Forwards the proceeds of a claim from Col. Morrison's estate on Columbian College (now George Washington University); hopes Clay is recovered from recent illness and accident.

did.unittitle: Force, Peter (1790-1868). Letter: Washington, to P.R. Fendall, Baltimore

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Has attended to requests Fendall made. (Force was an historian, a public printer and mayor of Washington).

did.unittitle: Force, Peter (1790-1868). Letter: to P.R. Fendall, Alexandria

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Mentions that a delegation from Baltimore will be arriving to see Fendall.

did.unittitle: Force, Peter (1790-1868). Letter: Washington, to Charles W. Goldsborough

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Force, as mayor of Washington, sends to Goldsborough, as president of the Board of Aldermen, a list of the bills he has signed.

did.unittitle: Force, Peter (1790-1868). Letter: Washington, to Rev. Joseph B. Felt, Boston

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Requests Felt to have copies made of various historical documents for sending to Force.

did.unittitle: Force, Peter (1790-1868). Letter: Washington, to Manning F. Force, Mass.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Encloses a draft of money for his son at Harvard Law School; mentions an interruption in his publishing projects.

did.unittitle: Forrest, Richard. Letter: Georgetown, to George Sibbald, Philadelphia

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Requests selling prices for wheat and other commodities; can fill Sibbald's sloop with them. He also comments on the health of mutual acquaintances.

did.unittitle: Forrest, Uriah (1757-1805). Letter: Georgetown, to Robert Morris

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Is greatly disappointed that Morris has not yet sent some money. (Forrest was a jurist and a Congressman from Maryland, 1793-1794).

did.unittitle: French, Benjamin B. (1800-1870). Letter: U.S., House of Representatives, to Dear Sir

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Encloses a printed copy of his poem "The Changes of Earth", with holograph corrections. (French was an author and the U.S. Commissioner of Public Buildings).

did.unittitle: Gales, Joseph (1786-1860). Letter: to Peter Force

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Requests Force to give some copies of a report to Mr. Rush. (Gales was a journalist and mayor of Washington, 1827-1830).

did.unittitle: Gales, Joseph (1786-1860). Letter: to Peter Force, Mayor's Office

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Asks for a meeting room for a convention of tobacco planters.

did.unittitle: Gales Joseph (1786-1860). Letter: Washington, to B.D. Taylor

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Conveys regret to Taylor that he and his family are not be able to make a visit because of the state of the roads.

did.unittitle: Gales, Joseph (1786-1860). Letter: to Thomas Ewing

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Concerns contracts for public printing.

did.unittitle: Gibbons, James (1834-1921). Letter: Baltimore, to A.P. Gorman

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Writes Senator Gorman of Maryland to ask him to use his influence to increase the appropriation 09. Joseph's Asylum in Washington. (Gibbons was the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Baltimore and the second American Cardinal).

did.unittitle: Gleyer, Jane. Letter: Washington City, to Maria Cox, Baltimore

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Regrets having to leave Baltimore for Washington; comments on large number of Congressmen living near her family. (Gleyer was a Washington resident).

did.unittitle: Goldsborough, Charles W. (1779-1843). Letter: Georgetown, to W. Hunter, Newport, RI

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Makes application for the post of Secretary of the Senate of the U.S. to Hunter, senator from Rhode Island. (Goldsborough was a Washington politician and served as president of the Washington Board of Aldermen).

did.unittitle: Green, Duff (1791-1875). Letter: Washington, to W.R. Smith

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Asks the banker Smith to discount a note signed by his brother. (Green was a businessman, a printer and a publisher for U.S. Congress, 1827-1833).

did.unittitle: Green, Duff (1791-1875). Letter: Dalton, GA, to H. Maynard

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Encloses a statement in reply to a newspaper article about his bill.

did.unittitle: Greenleaf, James (1765-1843). Letter: City of Washington, to Robert Watkins, GA

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Concerns a Georgia estate, the ownership of which is in doubt. Requests Watkins, a lawyer, to perform some legal work. (Greenleaf was a Washington land speculator).

did.unittitle: Greenough, Horatio (1805-1852). Letter: Florence, to George Washington, Greene, Rome

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Briefly mentions Washington statue; mentions quarrel with female acquaintance. (Greenough was an American sculptor who studied art in Rome. His most famous statue is of George Washington).

did.unittitle: Greenough, Horatio (1805-1852). Letter: Washington, DC, to William C. Preston, Columbia, SC

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Writes to former South Carolina Senator about proposed location of Washington statue.

did.unittitle: Hagner, Peter (1772-1850). Letter: Dept. of War, to Robert Brent, Washington

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Concerns payment of an account. (Hagner was an official in the War Department accounting office and the third auditor of the U.S. Treasury, 1817-1849).

did.unittitle: Hagner, Peter Valentine (1815-1893). Letter: New York, to Governor Morgan

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Relates that the Chief of Ordnance wants the use of New York state's ordnance. (Hagner was an ordnance officer in the U.S. Union Army).

did.unittitle: Hagner, Peter Valentine (1815-1893). Letter: West Troy, NY, to the District Attorney, Saratoga County

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Mentions an inspection tour.

did.unittitle: Harry, Richard. Letter: Washington, to Miss Wells

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Is glad she likes his writings; soon returns to New York.

did.unittitle: Henry, Joseph (1797-1878). Letter: Smithsonian Institution, to unidentified recipient

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Sends his autograph. (Henry was a scientific researcher on electricity and the first secretary and director of the Smithsonian institution in Washington, D.C.).

did.unittitle: Huntt, Henry (1792-1838). Document: Washington, DC, to Juan Guillaume Hyde de Neuville, 01/1819.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Printed document from Henry Huntt, George Bomford and Thomas Henderson, the Corresponding Committee of the Columbian Institute, requests submissions on subjects such as agriculture. (Huntt was a Washington, D.C. doctor).

did.unittitle: Jeffers, Madison. Letter: to Judges of the Circuit Court of the District of Columbia

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Defends self from accusations of improper behavior in removing a suspected runaway slave from the home of the Secretary to the British legation to the United States in Washington, D.C. (Jeffers was a constable removed from his post because of the incident described above).

did.unittitle: Joyce, John Alexander. (1842-1915). Love and Laughter: holograph, Louisville KY, 01/1863

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: (Joyce was an American lawyer and author).

did.unittitle: King, Horatio (1811-1897). Letter: Washington, to Lewis J. Cist, 09. Louis, MO

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Offers for sale to Cist, an autograph collector, a letter, dated 10 Dec. 1799, written by George Washington to James Anderson, concerning management of his farms. (King was an American editor, lawyer and U.S. postmaster).

did.unittitle: Lancaster, Joseph (1778-1838). Letter: Borough Road, to David Hall

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Mentions the poor condition of his aged father; expresses confidence in his ability to inspire his students. (Lancaster was an English educator, who established some schools in the U.S.).

did.unittitle: Lancaster, Joseph (1778-1838). Letter: Washington, to Elizabeth Lancaster, Philadelphia, 1818.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Describes his lectures in Baltimore and his intention to lecture in Congress in Washington, D.C.

did.unittitle: Lancaster, Joseph (1778-1838). Letter: Washington, to William Darlington

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Sends copies of his books.

did.unittitle: Latrobe, Benjamin Henry (1764-1820). Letter: Baltimore, to Langdon Cheves, Philadelphia

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Encloses for Cheves, president of the Bank of the United States, a bill from the British consul for some cement, of a type in use in England, for possible use on new Bank of the United States. (Latrobe was an American engineer and architect and designer of the restored U.S. Capitol after the War of 1812).

did.unittitle: Lee, Richard Bland (1761-1827). Letter: Washington, to the President and Directors of the Branch Bank of the US at Washington

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Lists notes of his held by the bank; requests that the names of endorsers be changed. (Lee was an American statesman and served as Congressman from Virginia, 1789-1795 and 1825-1827).

did.unittitle: Mackall, Louis (1867-1930). Letter: Georgetown, DC., to Hon. Judge J. Vinson

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Writes that they must assert property rights to the use of a road to their property. (Mackall was a Washington physician).

did.unittitle: Mason, John (fl., 1840-1850). Letter: Washington, to Gen. H. Dearborn, Boston

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Inquires about rumors that Boston builders plan to construct houses in Washington at a cheaper rate than the Washington builders; offers help to them as he approves this project; mentions his parents' continuing good health. (John Mason was possibly the son of John Mason (1766-1843).

did.unittitle: Mayo, Robert (1784-1864). Letter: Washington City, to Dr. Huntt, Board of Health

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Mayo encloses a resolution from citizens of Washington, protesting Washington Board of Health's action in excluding almost all vegetable production of the season from the Washington markets, in response to the cholera epidemic. (Mayo was an American physician and author).

did.unittitle: McKean, W.S. Letter: Washington, to the Theatrical Managers of America

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Asks theater managers to donate one percent of gross receipts for April 13, 1903 to the Memorial fund; p. 2 is facsimile of letter from actor Joseph Jefferson. (McKean was the Secretary of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Association of the United States).

did.unittitle: McLane, Allan (1746-1829). Letter: High 09. Coffey House, to James Mead, Philadelphia

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: States his opinion that after the Battle of Bladensburg (Aug. 24, 1814), the British forces very nearly captured the U.S. President. (McLane was an American Revolutionary War soldier and Delaware official. He was also a soldier in the War of 1812).

did.unittitle: McLean, John (1785-1861). Signature, not after 04/04/1861

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: (McLean was a U.S. Supreme Court Justice).

did.unittitle: Mills, Robert (1781-1855). Letter: Philadelphia, to Thomas Jefferson, Monticello

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Requests that Jefferson write him a letter of recommendation to President Madison so that he may become Surveyor of Public Buildings. (Mills was an engineer and architect of the Washington Monument in Washington, D.C.).

did.unittitle: Mills, Robert (1781-1855). Letter: to George Bancroft

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Writes to Bancroft, then Secretary of the Navy. Encloses sketches of facades for the War and Navy Department buildings. Describes area that will contain the Navy Department.

did.unittitle: Mills, Robert (1781-1855). Letter: to Jefferson Davis, Washington, 08/1854

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Writes to Davis, U.S. Secretary of War, about plans for buildings for the executive branch to be built in Washington, D.C., including spaces for the Treasury Department, State Department, Navy Department, Interior Department, and others.

did.unittitle: Mulledy, Thomas F. Letter: Georgetown College, to Hon. T. Burges, Washington

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Encloses statement of Burges's son's account. (Mulledy was the president of Georgetown College (now University), 1829-1837.

did.unittitle: Norton, Charles A. Long Bridge: holograph

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Poem memorializing Union soldiers killed in the Civil War. (Norton was a Union army soldier).

did.unittitle: Ould, Robert (1820-1882). Letter: Georgetown, DC, to the Secretary of the Navy, Washington

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Writes recommending someone for position of watchman. (Ould was a Washington lawyer and was later Assistant Secretary of War in the Confederacy).

did.unittitle: Page, Thomas Nelson (1853-1922). Letter: Hartford, Conn., to M.E. Waring, Chautauqua, N.Y.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Aurees to a speaking engagement. (Page was an American author and an ambassador to Italy, 1913-1919).

did.unittitle: Page, Thomas Nelson (1853-1922). Letter: London, to William Carey, N.Y.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Sends a revised article about his work Marse Chan; is greatly enjoying his tour of England.

did.unittitle: Page, Thomas Nelson (1853-1922). Letter: 1759 R 09. Washington, DC, to Robert Howard Russell, New York

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Suggests using a manuscript journal he has seen as a basis for a book by Russell.

did.unittitle: Page, Thomas Nelson (1853-1922). Letter: York Harbor, ME, to Robert H. Russell, NY

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Offers to the North American Review his article on lynching of Negros.

did.unittitle: Page, Thomas Nelson (1853-1922). Letter: 1759 R 09., to Frank W. Hoyt, Montclair, NJ

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Thanks Hoyt for a sympathetic review for his book of poems, probably The Coast of Bohemia. Defends the use of some of his rhymes.

did.unittitle: Payne, John Howard (1791-1852). Letter: Washington, to Elizabeth Payne

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Mentions recent violent arguments in the Senate, efforts to see governor Marcy, and visits with his friend Jonathan Meredith. (Payne was an American actor and playwright).

did.unittitle: Ream, Vinnie (1847-1914). Letter: to unidentified recipient, 18--.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Returns some items to the recipient. (Ream was an American sculptor and composer).

did.unittitle: Riggs, George Washington (1813-1881). Letter: Washington, DC, to W. Stone, Jr.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Encloses a note to which he has earlier referred. (Riggs was a Washington banker and one of the founders of Corcoran and Riggs banking firm).

did.unittitle: Riggs, George Washington (1813-1881). Letter: Washington, DC, to Joel Munsell, Albany

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Asks to be sent a copy of a Spanish work translated by Buckingham Smith.

did.unittitle: Roberdeau, Isaac (1763-1829). Letter: Washington, to Thomas Aspinwall

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Sends a letter to Mr. Perkins, who has made improvements in the use of steam power. (Roberdeau was a civil and military engineer and was chief of the Topographical Bureau in Washington).

did.unittitle: Rogé, Charlotte Fiske Bates, (1838-1916). Letter: Washington, DC, to Mrs. Edward Russell Jones

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Encloses her autograph and some others. (Rogé was an American author and compiler).

did.unittitle: Royall, Anne Newport (1769-1854). Letter: Washington, to Messrs. Green & Jarvis

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Thanks Green and Jarvis for advertising her book in their newspaper the United States Telegraph; deplores federal government corruption. (Royall was an American author and publisher).

did.unittitle: Seaton, William Winston (1785-1866). Letter: to an unidentified recipient

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Will send a carriage to take his friend to the U.S. Senate. (Seaton was a journalist, editor and mayor of Washington, D.C., 1840-1850).

did.unittitle: Seaton, William Winston (1785-1866). Letter: to "05 good friend", not after 1866

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Letter of introduction for an acquaintance.

did.unittitle: Seawell, Molly Elliot (1860-1916). Letter: Washington, DC, to "Dear Sir"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Mentions her recent short fiction. (Seawell was an American author).

did.unittitle: Singleton, Otho Robards (1814-1889). Letter: Washington, DC, to Mrs. Linn Boyd

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Describes the current state of social life in Washington and political events in Congress. (Singleton was a U.S. Congressman from Mississippi, 1853-1855, 1857-1861, 1875-1887).

did.unittitle: Southworth, Emma Dorothy Eliza Nevitte (1819-1899). Letter: Prospect Cottage

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Mentions her own sickness and that of Miss Gordon. (Southworth was an American author).

did.unittitle: Southworth, Emma Dorothy Eliza Nevitte (1819-1899). Letter: Yonkers, NY, to A.M. Irving

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Sends Irving an autograph.

did.unittitle: Southworth, Emma Dorothy Eliza Nevitte (1819-1899). Letter: Yonkers, NY, to Harry Watkins

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Praises his book His Worst Enemy. Mentions death of her nephew in a railroad accident and death of her sister Edith.

did.unittitle: Spofford, Harriet Elizabeth Prescott (1835-1921). Letter: to Mrs. E.R. Jones

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Sends autograph. (Spofford was an American author).

did.unittitle: Staughton, William (1770-1829). Letter: Georgetown SC, to Dr. Rogers, Philadelphia

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Dislikes Georgetown because of slavery and lack of success in religious endeavors; expects to leave in June. (Staughton was a Baptist clergyman and the first president of Columbian College (now George Washington University), 1822-1829).

did.unittitle: Stelle, Pontius Delare (b. 1763). Letter: City of Washington, to Jonathan Rhea, Trenton NJ

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Asks Rhea to help him raise money by the first of the next month. Stelle was a Washington hotel keeper and the brother of Rachel De Cow).

did.unittitle: Stelle, Pontius Delare (b. 1763). Letter: City of Washington, to Jonathan Rhea, Trenton, NJ

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Describes his family's dire financial situation; mentions the approaching British army and preparations in Washington for the city's defense.

did.unittitle: Stoddert, Benjamin (1751-1813). Letter: Georgetown, to Messrs. Samuel & J. Smith, Baltimore

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Concerns payment drawn on their establishment. (Stoddert was the first Secretary of the Navy, 1798-1801).

did.unittitle: Stoddert, Benjamin (1751-1813). Letter: Georgetown, to John Templeman, Philadelphia

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Describes a contract he has signed to buy a house in Georgetown,Washington, D.C. The letter indicates at time of sending he had enclosed a copy of the contract. That enclosure is not with this letter.

did.unittitle: Sykes, George (1802-1880). Letter: Washington, to "Dear Friend"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Mentions possibility that James Buchanan will accept a Supreme Court appointment, praises his actions in the controversy over the northwest border of the United States. (Sykes was a U.S. Representative from New Jersey).

did.unittitle: Thornton, William (1759-1828). Letter: Patent Office, to Caesar A. Rodney, Wilmington, DE

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Petitions Rodney as Attorney-General, in a humorous poem, to allow more funds for building the Capitol in Washington, D.C. (Thornton was the architect of the U.S. Capitol until 1802 and the Superintendent of Patents, 1802-1828).

did.unittitle: Thornton, William (1759-1828). Letter: City of Washington, to William Young

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Concerns payment for a shipment of goods.

did.unittitle: Thornton, William (1759-1828). Letter: to Mr. Leeton

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Concerns a notice that must appear in the paper three times a week for three weeks.

did.unittitle: Thornton, William (1759-1828). Letter: City of Washington, to Hyde de Neuville, NY

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Concerns some models of brick machines made by Adam Stewart of Philadelphia.

did.unittitle: United States Commissioners of the City of Washington. Letter: Washington, to George Washington, Mt. Vernon

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Enclosed is an estimate of the cost of houses Washington proposed to build in Washington; Washington later agreed to the terms for building two houses. (Commissioners appointed to lay out the city of Washington were Gustavus Scott, William Thornton and Alexander White).

did.unittitle: Van Ness, John P. (1770-1846). Letter: Washington, to Y. Eddy, Philadelphia

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Concerns a debt owed to the late W.M. Biddle of Philadelphia. (Van Ness was a U.S. Congressman from New York, 1801-1803, and the mayor of Washington, 1830-1834).

did.unittitle: Weightman, Roger Chew (1787-1876). Letter: Washington, to M.D. Phillips, Rochester, NY

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: States his correct address. (Weightman was Chief clerk of the U.S. patent office, June 1851-May 1853).

did.unittitle: Weightman, Roger Chew (1787-1876). Letter: Washington, to R.A. Shirer, Georgetown, DC

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Orders some ale.

did.unittitle: Wirt, William (1772-1834). Letter: Washington, to "Dear Sir"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Note of introduction. (Wirt was the United States Attorney-General, 1817-1829).

did.unittitle: Wolf, Simon (1836-1923). Letter: Washington, to Adam Badeau

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Invites him to attend the circumcision of his son. (Wolf was a Washington lawyer and author).

did.unittitle: Wylie, Andrew (1814-1905). Letter: Washington, to John Sherman

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Summary: Recommends an appointment to Sherman, Secretary of the Treasury. (Wylie was a judge of the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia, 1863-1885).%32882013824589

did.unittitle: Financial papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes financial papers such as bills, receipts, stock certificates, and checks dealing with banking, business, and transportation. The material covers the years 1796-1943. These papers include bank records from the Bank of Alexandria, Bank of Columbia, and the First National Bank of Washington. These records are from prominent citizens such as Joseph Henry from Corcoran & Riggs, John Mason, and the Metropolitan Police Department.

processinfo.head: Historical Context
processinfo.p: The term "prominent" is considered to be an aggrandizing term and usually would be avoided in archival description. The example in the Scope and Contents note of Series 2 was left as is, as the term "prominent" shows why the correspondence was aquired and preserved.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was revised in 2022 to address outdated descriptive language. During that revision, staff did not edit the description but instead added a context note. To see the description prior to review, please view the previous version of the W. Lloyd Wright finding aid.

did.unittitle: Financial Records--Bank 11 documents

odd.head: General note
odd.p: including one share of stock in the Bank of Alexandria, dated July 5, 1796 and an exchange for $1000, dated February 12, 1801, to John Mason, the second president of the Bank of Columbia. Also of note is a letter from General Walter Stewart, dated May 25, 1795, to John Templeman, an incorporator and director of the Bank of Columbia, concerning real estate in George Town and Washington.

did.unittitle: Financial Records--Bonds, Bounties, Certificates and Check 7 documents

odd.head: General note
odd.p: including an exchange for 115 pounds for Joseph Henry from Corcoran & Riggs to George Peabody & Co. and 4 certificates of land grants, each for 160 acres from the Department of the Interior.

did.unittitle: Financial Records--Bills and Receipt 24 documents

odd.head: General note
odd.p: including a receipt of $40 to William Wilson Corcoran, philanthropist, art patron and benefactor to the George Washington University, from John Mason for house rent and a bill for 2500 lbs. of hay sold to the United States Quartermaster General by Richard Bland Lee, statesman and member of the first Congress under the Constitution.

did.unittitle: Financial Records--Hotel bill 5 documents

odd.head: General note
odd.p: including a bill from Brown's Indian Queen Hotel, for May 7, 1838, a bill from the National Hotel, for February 11-22, 1835, and a bill from Willards' Hotel, for March 3, 1864.

did.unittitle: Financial Records--Metropolitan Police Check

odd.head: General note
odd.p: 16 checks from the First National Bank of Washington to the Department of Metropolitan Police, from November 14, 1867, to November 20, 1869.

did.unittitle: Financial Records--Shipping transportation 9 documents

odd.head: General note
odd.p: including transportation costs approved December 3, 1800, for taking Capt. Blackburn's company from Norfolk to Dumfries and a notice for a Furs & Peltries Auction on the 23rd of November, 1818, at the warehouses of the Superintendent of Indian Trade, George Town and the District of Columbia. Also includes a letter to the Judges of the Circuit Court of the United States, dated June 10, 1819, from Richard Wallach and John Graeff, appointed commissioners, for making certain turnpike roads in the District of Columbia.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series is composed of invitations, letters, wills, lottery tickets, proclamations, testimonies, DC Social Registers, and auction catalogues. These items range in date from 1794-1945 and concern the Washington lottery, indenture and slavery, newspapers, and Washington real estate. Materials of note include lottery tickets for Federal City lotteries of the late 19th century, and a collection of letters by Mary Clemmer (1839-1884), author and insightful chronicler of Washington life.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous--Churche Membership card of Elizabeth Ford to the Methodist Episcopal Church
Miscellaneous--Invitation 5 documents

odd.head: General note
odd.p: including an invitation from W.H. Winder for dinner at Willard's Hotel at 5 o'clock on 11 July 1852 and an invitation to Gideon Welles to be present at the Post Office Department on the occasion of raising a flag over the building, dated May 18, 1861.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous--Legal Records--Wills, appeal 6 documents

odd.head: General note
odd.p: including several wills and military discharge papers.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous--Letters from Civil War 8 documents, including general orders, requests for rations, ammunition and troops.
Miscellaneous--Letters of Phillip Barton Key and possible duel 4 documents

odd.head: General note
odd.p: including letters from Philip Barton Key and Captain C.A. May, as well as letters from mutual friends, J.M. Carlisle and John P. McLoughlin, who through their diplomacy prevented a duel between Barton and May. All dated in 1843.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous--Letters of Mary Clemmer Collection of 56 autograph letters signed

odd.head: General note
odd.p: An exceedingly interesting correspondence--refreshingly eloquent in praise of friends and in blame of foes. Miss Clemmer (Mary Clemmer Ames in the earlier letters) was widely known for her Washington correspondence, in which men and measures were discussed without fear or favor, in leading journals of the period.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous--Letters to W. Lloyd Wright 23 documents

odd.head: General note
odd.p: including invitations, letters of thanks for donations and certificates of membership and correspondence from the various societies to which Mr. Wright belonged, such as the Washington Society of Engineers, the Columbia Historical Society and the Society of Natives of the District of Columbia.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous--Lotterie 7 documents

odd.head: General note
odd.p: including several tickets for Federal City Lotteries, a right to three shares in the hotel lottery, 15 January 1794, and records of meetings of the Managers of the Federal City Lottery.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous--Newspaper 4 documents

odd.head: General note
odd.p: including a receipt and a supplement for the United States Telegraph.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous--Proclamation Proclamation of peace issued by Mayor James A. Blake

odd.head: General note
odd.p: announcing the end of the War of 1812.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous--Real Estate 17 documents

odd.head: General note
odd.p: including an indenture signed by John P. Van Ness, Mayor of Washington, on September 20, 1830 and a letter from W.H. Winder offering to sell the National Theatre for $55,000, dated March 30, 1855.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous--Slavery 2 documents

odd.head: General note
odd.p: including a notice of emancipation for Jacob Pendall, dated April 29, 1859.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous--Testimonial 4 documents

odd.head: General note
odd.p: including a petition to the President of the United States for the appointment of Benjamin B. French to the post of Marshal of the District of Columbia and a testimonial for the acceptance of an application for a clerkship in one of the executive departments.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous--Auction catalogue

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Auction catalogue for an exhibition and sale of items from the libraries of W. Lloyd Wright after his death, by order of his sister, as well as Florence H. Crane and others.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous Bookplate

odd.head: General note
odd.p: 2 bookplate stamps and several bookplates of W. Lloyd Wright.
